ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Writing philosophy papers.
mostly, you learn how to think about consciousness (various theories about what it is and how its explained) and cognition (how thought happens/what thought is). plus some random other topics.
Integrating scientific studies with philosophical arguments
This course delves into the most important concepts and theories in philosophy of mind.

Prior to this class, I had no experience whatsoever with philosophy. Throughout this class, I developed key skills in learning how to articulate my arguments related to a philosopher's ideas. I also learned how to debate the strengths and weaknesses of different arguments.
The course helped me develop my philosophical writing and gave an overview of the prevalent schools of thought regarding the philosophy of the mind.

Definitely developed the ability to write a philosophy paper, despite having never taken philosophy before. Made me more aware of areas of potential improvement in my other writing. Also learned quite a bit about consciousness, mental language, the mind and the body, AI, and more.
Learned about central topics in philosophy of mind like consciousness, intelligence, philosophy of cognitive science

This class was really excellent. I learned a ton of analytic philosophy skills, and a ton of subject matter knowledge about different schools of thought with regard to consciousness and cognitive science.

I learned about the fundamentals of philosophy of mind: consciousness, thought, belief, etc. This was my first real philosophy class as a CS major, and I thought I got a lot out of it. A lot of people debate how we could know if AI is conscious (if you haven't heard these debates yet, you will in the next few years). This class didn't answer the question for me, but it helped me understand the debate in a much more detailed way. I think it's been surprisingly useful for that!

Knowledge: major debates, positions, and arguments in philosophy of mind, with (what was to me) novel connections to contemporary work in cognitive science and machine learning
Skill: contextualizing a philosophical work in the history of the debate and the philosopher's project to better understand its assumptions, thrust, and significance (Professor Greco is extremely good at doing this and taught me how)
Insights: For the first time ever, I formed/updated substantial beliefs by taking a philosophy course. There is no pressure inherent in the design of the course to do this; the material was just extremely useful for my thinking.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: super interesting, good workload, greco is great at explaining very complicated things. weaknesses are few, but sometimes its hard to know how papers fit together or where greco wants us to go with them. ie its not always clear how various papers we read are supposed to be in conversation with one another.
A great course, not much to suggest for improvements

The strength is its style of each class, where you discuss the day's topic in little groups. This really made me think about the topic every class, and also it was interesting to hear what my classmates had to say, especially since this field has no "right answers."

I think this class was difficult for students who had never taken a philosophy class before. As someone who was considering majoring in cognitive science, I had no background for this philosophy class, so the adjustment to writing papers in a specific manner was difficult.

Strengths: The weekly homework assignments and class discussion really enabled engagement with course material

Weakness: N/A

Strengths: Professor Greco! He was amazing. So knowledgable in all the topics. He also is extremely organized - creates a handout for every class which help streamline harder readings and shed light on their most important parts. Also helps raise very interesting questions. He also gives thorough feedback on papers and is more than willing to meet either to discuss a paper idea or elaborate on feedback.

Weaknesses: Readings were sometimes (very) dense. Could make reading responses difficult, but wasn't too bad because you definitely don't need to fully understand the readings to raise a good question.
Enjoyed the mix of discussion and lecture. Readings were all very interesting.

Strengths: the format is great! I love the lecture and then discussion after. Also, the handouts are incredible  they lay everything out perfectly. 
Weaknesses: Honestly I sort of wished there had been more time for discussion? 50 minutes of lecture and 25 minutes of discussion was great when it happened, but sometimes lecture ran long and I didn't feel like we got to talk about the topic for as long as I'd liked.

The readings were interesting and engaging and Professor Greco always did a great job of synthesizing the key points in our handouts. I also felt that the weekly homework assignments were a great way to make sure I was keeping up with the class.

Professor Greco's note sheets are absolutely amazing. He writes down what he is going to talk about in the most brilliant format so you can follow along with the lecture. I also really liked the class format, which was lecture followed by small group discussions.

Sometimes it felt like the readings varied a bit in difficulty and length, and it might have been better for them to be more spread out. But this is mostly quibbling.

Strengths: Course structure was great by design: I loved the themes and readings, and assignments were reasonable in workload and flexible in choice of topics and overall efficiently helpful for learning. I especially enjoyed receiving feedback and further recommendations for my reading responses. Professor Greco is an extremely clear, knowledgeable, enthusiastic and engaging instructor. 

Weakness: Group discussions vary in quality and tend to be derailed. I wish this was a seminar with more moderated discussions instead.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I loved the material and although some of the readings were difficult for me to fully grasp on my own, I always came out of class understanding it and having had some interesting discussion about the material. Professor Greco is great at making things easy to understand.

qualified yes. if you dont like doing philosophy at all, dont take this course. of the people that like philosophy, (roughly) there are those who do it because they want answers to practical questions. and there are those who do it because they just love the method of arguing about philosophy. this course is best suited to the latter. if youre looking to formulate and defend a worldview, this wont be super fun for you. but if you love doing philosophy just because, this is an incredible class.
If they are interested in philosophy of mind and have prior experience with philosophy courses
I would definitely recommend this course to any cognitive science major! The philosophical concepts and topics are surprisingly related to any theme that you might pick in the major.
Yes.  Professor Greco was excellent (clear, engaging, and incredibly well-organized) and the material was interesting.
I would recommend this course to another student if they have a background in philosophy and are interested in considering the mind from a variety of perspectives.
Yes, the course is very interesting, both for those interested in AI and consciousness.

Yes - it was a new way of thinking about things! The papers can definitely be a bit challenging, but there is a lot of flexibility in what you can write about, so you can structure the papers so you're writing about something you genuinely find interesting. However, proceed with caution if there is your first philosophy course - definitely did not feel introductory.
Would highly recommend if someone is interested in either philosophy or cognitive science. Topics are really interesting and relevant outside of just philosophy.
Absolutely, if they're at all interested in philosophy of mind.

If you like reading and discussing philosophy and you are interested in philosophy of mind, you will like this course. I would highly recommend it! If you think you would be bored about talking about consciousness for half a semester and reading variations and responses on the same few arguments, then maybe take a broader philosophy class. I personally really enjoyed the level of detail we went into.

Highly recommend for philosophy majors (would probably also recommend for other majors, but cannot speak from my experience): even if you are not particularly interested in phil of mind (which I would think you have good reason to be), there are deep and interesting connections to metaphysics and epistemology in early modern philosophy and also features many seminal contemporary thinkers & works e.g. Fodor, Chomsky, Dennett. You have control over how much to put in this class and could learn at lot at any level of commitment (I think I put in a lot and have not hit diminishing returns).
